The fluorescent lights hummed overhead in the cramped basement of Tony's Electrical Services, casting harsh shadows across the concrete walls lined with coils of copper wire and junction boxes. Marcus Rivera wiped the sweat from his forehead with the back of his calloused hand, leaving a streak of electrical tape residue across his dark skin. At thirty-two, he had spent the better part of a decade crawling through the bowels of Newark's aging buildings, rewiring circuits and fixing the endless parade of electrical problems that plagued the city's infrastructure.

But today felt different. Today, something had shifted inside him like a breaker switching positions.

"You're telling me you want to do what now?" Tony Castellano's voice cracked with disbelief as he emerged from behind his cluttered desk, nearly knocking over a tower of invoices that threatened to topple onto the oil-stained floor. His thick Brooklyn accent made everything sound like an accusation, even when he was genuinely confused.

Marcus straightened up, rolling his shoulders back in a gesture of determination that surprised even himself. "I said I want to learn sword fighting. Fencing, specifically. There's a club over in Hoboken that teaches it."

Tony's weathered face contorted into an expression somewhere between amusement and concern. He had known Marcus since the younger man had started as an apprentice seven years ago, fresh out of trade school with calloused hands and an eagerness to learn that had impressed even Tony's cynical heart. But this was something entirely different.

"Kid, you been breathing too many electrical fumes or something? Sword fighting? What are you, gonna join the circus?" Tony's laugh came out as more of a wheeze, the result of too many years smoking cigarettes during lunch breaks on construction sites.

The question hung in the air between them like smoke from an overloaded circuit. Marcus had been asking himself the same thing for weeks, ever since he had stumbled across a late-night documentary about Olympic fencing while channel surfing in his studio apartment. Something about the precise movements, the calculated aggression, the way the fencers moved like dancers engaged in a deadly ballet had captured his imagination in a way nothing had for years.

"I don't know, Tony. I just know I need to do something different. Something that isn't crawling around in dusty crawl spaces fixing other people's mistakes." Marcus picked up a length of twelve-gauge wire and began unconsciously coiling it into perfect loops, a nervous habit he had developed during his apprenticeship.

Tony studied his best employee with the shrewd eyes of a man who had been running a small business in Newark for over twenty years. He had seen good workers come and go, watched some burn out from the physical demands of the job, others move on to bigger companies or start their own operations. But Marcus was different – reliable, skilled, and honest to a fault. Losing him would be a disaster Tony couldn't afford.

"Look, Marcus, I get it. Sometimes a man needs a hobby. But sword fighting? Come on. Why not take up bowling like a normal person? Join a softball league. Hell, learn to play poker. But waving around sharp pieces of metal? That's how you end up in the emergency room, or worse."

Marcus set down the coiled wire and met Tony's gaze directly. "It's not just waving around sharp pieces of metal. It's a sport. An art form. These people train for years, decades even. There's strategy involved, technique, discipline."

"Discipline?" Tony snorted. "You want discipline? Try running a small business in this economy. Try dealing with customers who think electricity should be free and contractors who pay their bills six months late. That's discipline."

The conversation was interrupted by the arrival of Mrs. Chen, an elderly woman who lived in one of the renovated brownstones on the north side of the city. She clutched a plastic grocery bag filled with what appeared to be electrical outlets and light switches, her face bearing the expression of someone who had been dealing with home improvement projects far beyond her expertise.

"Excuse me," she said hesitantly, her voice carrying a slight accent. "My grandson, he try to fix bathroom light. Now nothing work upstairs. You can help?"

Tony's demeanor immediately shifted into professional mode. "Of course, Mrs. Chen. Marcus here will take a look at what you've got and we'll send someone over this afternoon." He shot Marcus a meaningful look. "Won't we, Marcus?"

"Absolutely," Marcus replied, already reaching for his tool bag. This was the part of the job he actually enjoyed – solving problems, figuring out what had gone wrong and making it right again. It was satisfying work, even if it wasn't particularly glamorous.

As Mrs. Chen explained the situation in a mixture of English and what sounded like Mandarin, gesturing expressively with her free hand, Marcus found his mind wandering. He imagined himself in white fencing gear, mask obscuring his face, holding a slim blade that caught the light as he moved through the precise choreography of an attack sequence he had watched online the night before.

"Marcus!" Tony's sharp voice snapped him back to reality. "Mrs. Chen asked you a question."

"Sorry," Marcus mumbled, feeling heat rise in his cheeks. "What was that?"

Mrs. Chen repeated her question about whether the problem might be related to the circuit breaker, and Marcus launched into a detailed explanation of how electrical circuits worked and what might have caused the outage. As he spoke, he noticed Tony nodding approvingly – this was the Marcus he knew, the one who could diagnose electrical problems with the confidence of a doctor reading symptoms.

After Mrs. Chen left with assurances that help would arrive by three o'clock, Tony returned to their earlier conversation with the persistence of a dog with a favorite bone.

"See, that's what I'm talking about. You're good at this stuff, Marcus. You've got natural instincts for electrical work. Why throw that away to play with swords?"

Marcus felt a familiar frustration building in his chest. "I'm not throwing anything away. I'm talking about taking lessons a couple nights a week. It's not like I'm quitting my job to become a professional... what do you call them... a musketeer or something."

"Musketeer," Tony repeated flatly. "Right. And I suppose next you'll be wanting time off to go fight duels in the park."

"It's not duels, Tony. It's sport fencing. They use electronic scoring systems and everything. It's completely safe."

Tony walked over to the small window that looked out onto the street, watching the afternoon traffic crawl past in the humid August heat. Newark in summer was like working inside an oven, and the air conditioning unit in the shop had been making concerning noises for weeks – another repair that would have to wait until they had time and money to address it properly.

"You know what's not completely safe?" Tony said without turning around. "Climbing around on scaffolding forty feet off the ground. Working with live electrical panels. Crawling through basements that haven't been properly ventilated in fifty years. But we do it anyway, because it's our job. Because it puts food on the table and pays the rent."

Marcus understood the implication. Tony wasn't just worried about the safety aspects of sword fighting – he was worried about his employee's priorities, about whether Marcus was starting to lose focus on the work that mattered.

"I hear what you're saying," Marcus said carefully. "But this isn't about the job. This is about having something in my life besides work. Something that challenges me in a different way."

Tony finally turned away from the window, his expression softer but still skeptical. "Look, kid, I've been doing this a long time. I've seen guys go through midlife crises before. Usually it involves buying a motorcycle or dating someone half their age. Sword fighting is a new one for me, but the principle is the same. You're looking for something to make you feel young again, or tough, or I don't know what."

"Maybe you're right," Marcus admitted. "But maybe that's not necessarily a bad thing."

The admission seemed to catch Tony off guard. He had been prepared for argument, for defensive protests, not for this kind of honest self-reflection.

"Besides," Marcus continued, "I already signed up for the introductory class. It starts next Thursday."

Tony's eyebrows shot up toward his receding hairline. "You already signed up? Without talking to me about the schedule?"

"It's Thursday night, seven to nine. We're usually done with calls by six, and I wasn't scheduled for any overtime work this week."

"That's not the point, Marcus. The point is that you made a commitment without thinking about how it might affect your work here. What if we get an emergency call? What if Mrs. Chen's electrical problem turns out to be more complicated than we thought and we need to work late?"

Marcus felt his patience beginning to fray around the edges. "Then I'll handle it, same as always. But I can't put my entire life on hold just in case something might happen with work."

The conversation was heading toward an argument, and both men seemed to realize it at the same time. Tony rubbed his forehead with the palm of his hand, leaving his gray hair sticking up at odd angles.

"All right," he said finally. "All right. You want to take fencing lessons, take fencing lessons. Just don't come crying to me when you poke somebody's eye out."

Marcus smiled for the first time since the conversation had started. "I don't think that's how it works, Tony. They wear masks and everything."

"Yeah, well, we'll see."

The rest of the afternoon passed in relative normalcy. Marcus drove out to Mrs. Chen's house and discovered that her grandson had indeed created an impressive electrical disaster by attempting to install a dimmer switch without first turning off the circuit breaker. It took two hours to sort out the wiring and replace a blown fuse, but Mrs. Chen was so grateful she insisted on sending him home with a container of homemade dumplings.

That evening, Marcus sat in his small apartment eating Mrs. Chen's dumplings and watching fencing videos on his laptop. His living room was spartanly furnished – a secondhand couch, a coffee table made from a piece of reclaimed wood and some metal pipes, and a bookshelf containing mostly technical manuals and a few paperback novels he had picked up at yard sales.

The apartment reflected Marcus's practical nature and limited budget, but it also revealed something else: a life that had become routine to the point of stagnation. He went to work, came home, ate dinner, watched television, and went to bed. Weekends were spent doing laundry, grocery shopping, and catching up on sleep. It was a perfectly functional existence, but it lacked the spark of genuine excitement or purpose.

As he watched Olympic fencers move across his laptop screen with fluid precision, Marcus tried to imagine himself learning those same movements. Could his hands, so used to gripping wire strippers and voltage meters, adapt to holding a sword? Could his body, accustomed to the practical movements of manual labor, learn the elegant geometry of attack and defense?

The doubts that had been lurking at the edges of his consciousness began to surface. Tony wasn't entirely wrong – this was an unusual hobby for someone in his situation. Most of the people in the fencing videos looked like they came from a different world entirely, a world of private lessons and expensive equipment and country club memberships.

But something stubborn in Marcus's nature pushed back against these doubts. He had always been good at learning new skills, at figuring out how things worked and mastering the techniques required to do them well. Electrical work itself had once seemed impossibly complex, full of mysterious concepts and dangerous variables. Yet he had learned it, had become good at it, had even found satisfaction in it.

Why should fencing be any different?The following Thursday evening found Marcus standing outside the Hoboken Community Center, a converted warehouse building that housed everything from yoga classes to pottery workshops. The parking lot was filled with an eclectic mix of vehicles – hybrid sedans, aging SUVs, and a few expensive European cars that seemed out of place in the industrial neighborhood. Marcus had changed out of his work clothes into a clean pair of jeans and a polo shirt, but he still felt underdressed and uncertain as he approached the glass doors that led to the main entrance.

Inside, the building buzzed with the activity of various evening classes. Through one doorway, he could see a group of middle-aged women stretching on yoga mats while soft music played in the background. Another room contained what appeared to be a book club, their animated discussion punctuated by gestures toward paperback novels and wine glasses. The smell of clay and paint from the art studios mixed with the industrial scent of the old warehouse, creating an atmosphere that was both creative and slightly overwhelming.

Marcus followed the signs toward the gymnasium, his work boots echoing against the polished concrete floors. The closer he got to his destination, the more his nervousness transformed into something resembling excitement. This was really happening – he was about to try something completely outside his normal experience, something that had nothing to do with electrical codes or circuit breakers or the familiar rhythms of his daily routine.

The gymnasium was larger than he had expected, with high ceilings and fluorescent lighting that reminded him uncomfortably of Tony's shop. But instead of electrical equipment and wire spools, this space was set up with what looked like long rectangular strips marked out on the floor. At one end of the room, a woman in her forties was arranging equipment on a folding table – masks that looked like metallic mesh, strange-looking swords with curved hand guards, and what appeared to be electronic scoring devices with trailing wires.

She looked up as Marcus entered, offering a welcoming smile that immediately put him more at ease. Her dark hair was pulled back in a practical ponytail, and she wore a fitted athletic shirt that suggested someone who stayed in excellent physical condition without making a show of it. There was something in her bearing that reminded Marcus of the military veterans he sometimes worked with on construction sites – a quiet confidence that came from extensive training and discipline.

"You must be Marcus," she said, extending her hand for a firm handshake. "I'm Elena Vasquez. I run the fencing program here. Welcome to what I like to call the most civilized form of combat known to humanity."

Marcus found himself smiling at her description. "Thanks for letting me try this out. I have to admit, I'm not entirely sure what I've gotten myself into."

Elena laughed, a sound that was both warm and slightly mischievous. "That's probably the most honest thing anyone has said to me in weeks. Most people show up convinced they're going to be the next Olympic champion after watching too many movies. The fact that you're admitting you don't know what to expect tells me you might actually have the right attitude for this."

Over the next few minutes, other students began filtering into the gymnasium. Marcus was surprised by the diversity of the group – there was a teenager who looked like he might still be in high school, a woman in her sixties who moved with the careful precision of someone managing arthritis, a man about Marcus's age wearing a business suit who had apparently come straight from an office job, and several others who defied easy categorization. It wasn't the homogeneous group of privileged athletes he had been half-expecting.

Elena gathered the newcomers together at one end of the gym while the more experienced students began their own warm-up routine. Marcus watched them out of the corner of his eye, noting how they moved through stretching exercises that seemed designed specifically for fencing. Their movements had a fluidity that spoke of years of practice, but there was nothing intimidating about their demeanor. If anything, they seemed genuinely enthusiastic about the presence of new students.

"Before we put any equipment in your hands," Elena began, "I want to talk about what fencing actually is and what it isn't. It's not sword fighting in the medieval sense – we're not trying to hack each other to pieces with broadswords. It's not about anger or aggression or proving how tough you are. Modern sport fencing is about strategy, timing, and precision. It's about reading your opponent, finding the perfect moment to attack, and executing techniques that have been refined over centuries."

She picked up one of the swords from the equipment table, holding it with the casual familiarity of someone who had been handling such weapons for decades. The blade was thin and flexible, nothing like the heavy medieval swords Marcus had seen in movies. In Elena's hand, it looked almost delicate, more like a precision instrument than a weapon.

"This is a foil," she explained, demonstrating a few basic movements. "It's one of three weapons used in modern fencing, and it's what we'll be starting with tonight. The target area is limited to the torso, and only the tip of the blade can score touches. The rules might seem arbitrary at first, but they're designed to teach fundamental techniques that apply to all forms of swordplay."

Elena demonstrated the basic stance, and Marcus tried to mirror her movements. His legs felt awkward in the required position, with one foot pointed forward and the other angled to the side, his weight distributed in a way that felt unnatural after years of standing and walking in work boots. His arm position was even more challenging – holding the imaginary sword with his wrist straight and his elbow controlled, maintaining a position that was both relaxed and ready for instant action.

"Don't worry about feeling awkward," Elena said, apparently reading the expression on his face. "Everyone feels like they're trying to pat their head and rub their belly at the same time during their first lesson. Fencing uses muscles and coordination patterns that most people never develop in normal life. It takes time for your body to adapt."

The businessman next to Marcus was having similar difficulties, his expensive suit jacket riding up as he tried to maintain the proper arm position. The teenager seemed to be picking up the movements more quickly, but even he looked uncertain and slightly off-balance. Only the older woman seemed comfortable, and Elena noticed Marcus watching her.

"Margaret has been coming to my classes for three years," Elena explained. "She started fencing after her retirement because she wanted a physical activity that would also challenge her mentally. She's probably the most technically sound fencer in our intermediate group now."

Margaret smiled at the compliment but didn't lose her focus on the movements Elena was demonstrating. There was something inspiring about her dedication, the way she approached each technique with the patience and attention to detail of someone who understood that mastery came through consistent practice rather than natural talent.

For the next hour, Elena led the beginners through a series of basic exercises designed to introduce the fundamental movements of fencing. They practiced advancing and retreating while maintaining proper stance, learned how to extend their sword arm in a basic attack, and began to understand the concept of distance – how close you needed to be to your opponent to land a touch, and how that distance constantly changed as both fencers moved.

Marcus found the mental aspects of the lesson as challenging as the physical ones. In electrical work, problems generally had clear solutions that could be determined through systematic troubleshooting. But fencing seemed to involve constant adaptation to changing circumstances, reading subtle cues from an opponent's body language and movements, making split-second decisions based on incomplete information. It was like trying to solve a puzzle that kept changing its parameters.

By the end of the class, Marcus's shirt was soaked with sweat and his legs ached from maintaining unfamiliar positions, but he felt more energized than he had in months. There was something addictive about the complete focus that fencing required – for those two hours, he had been entirely present in the moment, not thinking about work problems or bills or the general dissatisfaction that had been gnawing at him for so long.

As the students began packing up equipment and saying their goodbyes, Elena approached Marcus with an evaluative expression. "So, what did you think? Are you going to come back next week, or are you going to decide this was an interesting experiment that you're glad to have tried once?"

Marcus considered the question seriously. His body was telling him that he had just put it through something unusual and demanding. His mind was still processing the complexity of what he had been introduced to. But underneath the physical discomfort and mental fatigue, he felt something that had been missing from his life for too long – a sense of genuine challenge and possibility.

"I'll be back," he said, surprising himself with the certainty in his voice. "I have no idea if I'll be any good at this, but I definitely want to find out."

Elena nodded approvingly. "That's the right answer. Natural talent is nice, but it's not nearly as important as genuine interest and willingness to work at something. I've seen plenty of naturally gifted athletes wash out because they weren't prepared for how much effort it takes to really learn fencing. And I've seen people who seemed hopeless at first become excellent fencers because they refused to give up."

As Marcus drove home through the humid Newark night, he found himself replaying the evening's lesson in his mind. His right arm still felt the memory of holding an imaginary sword, and his legs reminded him of the unusual demands of fencing footwork every time he pressed the brake pedal. But more than the physical sensations, he was struck by how different the experience had been from anything else in his recent life.

For years, his evenings had followed a predictable pattern of dinner, television, and early bedtime in preparation for another day of familiar work. Tonight had broken that pattern completely, introducing him to new people, new ideas, and new ways of thinking about physical movement and strategy. It felt like waking up after a long period of sleepwalking through his daily routine.

When he arrived at his apartment, Marcus found himself looking at his living space with fresh eyes. The sparse furniture and bare walls that had seemed practical and sufficient now looked almost monk-like in their austerity. It occurred to him that somewhere along the way, he had stopped thinking of this as a home and started treating it as merely a place to sleep between work days. The realization wasn't particularly comfortable, but it felt like an important recognition of how narrow his life had become.

He made himself a sandwich and sat at his small kitchen table, laptop open to fencing videos once again. But now, instead of watching with the detached curiosity of someone trying to understand a foreign activity, he found himself analyzing techniques and trying to understand the tactical thinking behind various attacks and defenses. The movements that had seemed mysterious and arbitrary a week ago now had context and meaning, even if he was still far from understanding their subtleties.

Marcus spent the next hour taking notes on basic fencing concepts, creating a study guide that he could refer to between lessons. It was the same systematic approach he had used when learning electrical work – breaking complex skills down into component parts, understanding the principles behind specific techniques, building a foundation of knowledge that could support more advanced learning. The familiar process of active learning felt good, reminding him that he was capable of mastering new and challenging skills when he put his mind to it.

By the time he finally went to bed, Marcus realized that Thursday had become something to look forward to rather than just another day of the week. It was a small change, but it felt significant – the first crack in the routine that had been governing his life for too long. As he drifted off to sleep, his dreams were filled with images of precise movements and strategic thinking, of challenges that had nothing to do with electrical circuits or repair schedules or the comfortable predictability of work he had mastered years ago.**Chapter 2**

The alarm clock's shrill cry cut through Marcus's dreams at 5:30 AM, just as it had every weekday morning for the past seven years. But this Friday morning felt different somehow, as if the previous evening's fencing lesson had shifted something fundamental in his perception of the world. As he went through his usual routine of shower, coffee, and work clothes, Marcus found himself moving through the familiar motions with a new awareness of his body's positioning and balance. The memory of Elena's instructions about proper stance and footwork lingered in his muscle memory, making him conscious of how he distributed his weight while standing at the bathroom mirror, how he held his shoulders while reaching for his coffee mug.

The drive to Tony's shop took him through the same Newark streets he had been navigating for years, past the same collection of aging apartment buildings, corner stores, and small businesses that formed the landscape of his daily existence. But this morning, instead of the usual mental rehearsal of the day's scheduled service calls, Marcus found himself thinking about the tactical concepts Elena had introduced during the lesson. The idea that effective fencing required constant analysis of distance, timing, and opponent behavior seemed to apply to more than just sword fighting. Even navigating morning traffic involved similar calculations about speed, position, and predicting other drivers' intentions.

Tony was already at the shop when Marcus arrived, hunched over a stack of invoices with the concentrated expression of a man trying to make numbers add up to something more favorable than reality suggested. The coffee maker was gurgling in the corner, filling the small office space with the bitter aroma that served as the shop's unofficial morning alarm clock. Tony looked up as Marcus entered, his weathered face showing the kind of skeptical curiosity that suggested he had been thinking about their previous conversation regarding sword fighting.

"So," Tony said without preamble, "how did your little sword fighting adventure go last night? You still got both eyes? All your fingers still attached?" His tone carried the particular brand of sarcasm that Tony deployed when he wanted to express concern without admitting to actual worry about his employee's well-being.

Marcus hung his jacket on the hook near the door and poured himself a cup of coffee from the perpetually brewing pot that had been serving the shop's caffeine needs for longer than anyone could remember. The coffee was strong enough to wake the dead and roughly half as smooth, but it was hot and reliable, which were the only qualities that mattered at six in the morning in a Newark electrical repair shop.

"It was actually pretty interesting," Marcus replied, settling into his usual chair across from Tony's cluttered desk. "More complicated than I expected, but in a good way. It's not just about waving swords around. There's a lot of strategy involved, reading your opponent, timing your attacks." As he spoke, Marcus realized he was unconsciously sitting straighter, his shoulders squared in a way that echoed the posture Elena had emphasized during the lesson.

Tony's eyebrows rose slightly at this description, his expression shifting from skeptical amusement to something approaching genuine interest. In all the years he had known Marcus, Tony had never heard his employee speak with such enthusiasm about anything outside of electrical work. The younger man's usual demeanor was competent but reserved, professional but not particularly passionate. This new energy was unexpected and, Tony had to admit, somewhat intriguing.

"Strategy, huh?" Tony mused, leaning back in his chair with a creak of protesting springs. "Like what kind of strategy? I thought sword fighting was just about being faster than the other guy." His question carried genuine curiosity rather than mockery, suggesting that despite his earlier objections, he was interested in understanding what had captured Marcus's attention so completely.

Marcus found himself explaining the concepts of distance, timing, and tactical thinking that Elena had introduced, describing how fencers had to constantly analyze their opponent's tendencies and adapt their approach accordingly. As he talked, he noticed that Tony was listening with the same focused attention he brought to complex electrical problems, occasionally nodding or asking clarifying questions. It occurred to Marcus that the tactical thinking required for fencing wasn't entirely unlike the diagnostic skills that made Tony such an effective troubleshooter when dealing with particularly challenging electrical issues.

Their conversation was interrupted by the arrival of Jimmy Castellano, Tony's nephew and the shop's other full-time electrician. Jimmy was in his mid-twenties, with the kind of effortless confidence that came from growing up in a family business and never having to wonder whether he would have steady employment. He possessed solid technical skills and a good work ethic, but he also had a tendency to approach new ideas with the skepticism of someone who had never needed to question the fundamental assumptions of his life.

"Morning, Uncle Tony. Marcus," Jimmy nodded to each of them as he grabbed his own cup of coffee and settled into the third chair that completed the shop's informal morning briefing area. "What's this I hear about you taking sword fighting lessons?" His tone suggested that he had heard about Marcus's new hobby from Tony and was prepared to find the whole thing amusing.

Marcus felt a familiar defensive tension rise in his chest, the same feeling he had experienced during his conversation with Tony the previous day. There was something about having to justify his interest in fencing that brought out his stubborn streak, a reaction to the implicit suggestion that his choices were somehow unreasonable or inappropriate for someone in his position. He was tired of feeling like he needed permission to pursue interests that had nothing to do with his work or other people's expectations.

"I had my first lesson last night," Marcus replied evenly, making an effort to keep any defensiveness out of his voice. "It's called fencing, and it's an Olympic sport. The instructor is a woman who competed nationally before she started teaching." As he provided these details, Marcus realized he was trying to establish the legitimacy of his new interest, to demonstrate that it wasn't just a whim or a temporary fascination with something exotic.

Jimmy's expression suggested that he was processing this information with the same confusion his uncle had displayed initially. "Fencing," he repeated slowly, as if testing the word's taste in his mouth. "Like, with swords and masks and all that? I thought that was something rich people did at country clubs." His comment carried no particular malice, but it reflected the same assumptions Marcus had been wrestling with himself – the idea that certain activities belonged to certain social classes and that crossing those boundaries was somehow inappropriate.

The observation stung because it contained enough truth to be uncomfortable. Most of the fencing videos Marcus had watched did feature athletes who looked like they came from privileged backgrounds, people who had access to expensive coaching and equipment from an early age. The fencing club in Hoboken was located in a community center rather than an exclusive facility, but even so, Marcus wondered whether he would eventually encounter the kind of social barriers Jimmy was alluding to.

Tony seemed to sense the direction his nephew's comments were heading and intervened with the diplomatic skills that had helped him maintain relationships with customers and employees for over two decades. "Jimmy, Marcus can spend his free time however he wants. As long as he shows up for work ready to do his job, what he does in the evenings is his own business." The statement was delivered in a tone that suggested the subject was closed, but Tony's expression indicated that he was still trying to understand his employee's motivations.

The morning briefing continued with a review of the day's scheduled service calls, a familiar ritual that helped organize their work and ensure that nothing important fell through the cracks. Marcus had two residential calls, including a follow-up visit to Mrs. Chen's house to check on the electrical work he had completed earlier in the week. Jimmy was assigned to a commercial job at a small manufacturing plant that had been experiencing problems with their main electrical panel. Tony would handle the administrative work and be available for emergency calls or situations that required his greater experience.

As they gathered their tools and prepared to head out for the day's work, Marcus found himself looking forward to the familiar challenges of electrical repair with renewed appreciation. The previous evening's fencing lesson had reminded him why he had originally been drawn to electrical work – the satisfaction of understanding complex systems, the problem-solving skills required to diagnose and fix issues, the sense of accomplishment that came from restoring functionality to something that had been broken. These were the same qualities that made fencing appealing, just applied in a completely different context.

The drive to his first appointment took Marcus through a neighborhood of small houses and converted apartments, the kind of working-class area where most of his residential customers lived. These were people who dealt with the same economic pressures he faced, who had to balance the cost of necessary repairs against tight household budgets. Marcus had always felt comfortable in these environments, appreciated for his honest assessments and fair pricing rather than judged for his background or social status.

His first call was at a duplex where the tenant was experiencing problems with outlets that worked intermittently, a classic symptom of loose connections or deteriorating wire nuts. The woman who met him at the door was probably in her fifties, with the tired expression of someone juggling multiple jobs and family responsibilities. She explained the problem while leading him to the affected areas, apologizing for the cluttered state of the apartment in the way that people do when they're embarrassed about circumstances beyond their control.

Marcus went to work with the methodical approach that had become second nature over the years, testing circuits, checking connections, and gradually isolating the source of the problem. As he worked, he found himself applying the same kind of systematic thinking Elena had emphasized in the fencing lesson – gathering information, analyzing patterns, forming hypotheses, and testing them until the solution became clear. The parallel between electrical troubleshooting and fencing strategy wasn't something he had considered before, but both activities required patience, attention to detail, and the ability to adapt when initial assumptions proved incorrect.

The actual repair took about an hour once he had identified several loose connections in a junction box that had been installed years earlier by someone with more enthusiasm than skill. As Marcus tightened wire nuts and tested circuits, he found himself explaining the work to his customer with more energy and detail than usual. The previous evening's experience of learning something completely new had reminded him of the satisfaction that came from understanding how complex systems worked, and he wanted to share some of that knowledge with someone who would benefit from it.

His customer listened attentively as Marcus described why electrical connections loosened over time and what signs to watch for that might indicate developing problems. Her questions were practical and intelligent, focused on how to maintain her home's electrical system and avoid expensive emergency repairs. The conversation reminded Marcus of why he had originally chosen electrical work as a career – it was a field where his skills could make a real difference in people's lives, where the knowledge he had accumulated over the years had practical value for others.

The second appointment of the day was at Mrs. Chen's house, where he had promised to check on the electrical work he had completed earlier in the week. Mrs. Chen greeted him with the kind of warm hospitality that made residential service calls a pleasure, offering tea and insisting that he try some homemade cookies she had prepared specially for his visit. The electrical work was functioning perfectly, but she seemed genuinely pleased to have someone to talk to about the various home improvement projects she was planning.

As they discussed her plans for updating the kitchen lighting, Marcus found himself thinking about the different kinds of relationships that developed through his work. Mrs. Chen represented the best aspect of being a service electrician – the opportunity to build ongoing relationships with customers who valued his expertise and trusted his recommendations. These connections provided a sense of professional satisfaction that went beyond simply completing technical tasks and collecting payment.

During his lunch break, Marcus drove to a small park near the Passaic River where he often went to eat his sandwich and decompress between morning and afternoon appointments. The park was nothing fancy – a few picnic tables, some aging playground equipment, and a walking path that followed the river for about half a mile – but it provided a peaceful contrast to the industrial landscape that dominated most of Newark. As he ate, Marcus found himself reviewing the previous evening's fencing lesson and thinking about the upcoming Thursday session with an anticipation that surprised him.

The afternoon brought a more challenging service call at an older apartment building where the landlord was trying to upgrade the electrical system to meet current code requirements while spending as little money as possible. This type of job required diplomatic skills as much as technical expertise, finding ways to bring aging wiring up to safety standards without bankrupting property owners who were operating on thin margins. The fluorescent lights hummed overhead in the cramped basement of Tony's Electrical Services, casting harsh shadows across the concrete walls lined with coils of copper wire and junction boxes. Marcus Rivera wiped the sweat from his forehead with the back of his calloused hand, leaving a streak of electrical tape residue across his dark skin. At thirty-two, he had spent the better part of a decade crawling through the bowels of Newark's aging buildings, rewiring circuits and fixing the endless parade of electrical problems that plagued the city's infrastructure.

But today felt different. Today, something had shifted inside him like a breaker switching positions.

"You're telling me you want to do what now?" Tony Castellano's voice cracked with disbelief as he emerged from behind his cluttered desk, nearly knocking over a tower of invoices that threatened to topple onto the oil-stained floor. His thick Brooklyn accent made everything sound like an accusation, even when he was genuinely confused.

Marcus straightened up, rolling his shoulders back in a gesture of determination that surprised even himself. "I said I want to learn sword fighting. Fencing, specifically. There's a club over in Hoboken that teaches it."

Tony's weathered face contorted into an expression somewhere between amusement and concern. He had known Marcus since the younger man had started as an apprentice seven years ago, fresh out of trade school with calloused hands and an eagerness to learn that had impressed even Tony's cynical heart. But this was something entirely different.

"Kid, you been breathing too many electrical fumes or something? Sword fighting? What are you, gonna join the circus?" Tony's laugh came out as more of a wheeze, the result of too many years smoking cigarettes during lunch breaks on construction sites.

The question hung in the air between them like smoke from an overloaded circuit. Marcus had been asking himself the same thing for weeks, ever since he had stumbled across a late-night documentary about Olympic fencing while channel surfing in his studio apartment. Something about the precise movements, the calculated aggression, the way the fencers moved like dancers engaged in a deadly ballet had captured his imagination in a way nothing had for years.

"I don't know, Tony. I just know I need to do something different. Something that isn't crawling around in dusty crawl spaces fixing other people's mistakes." Marcus picked up a length of twelve-gauge wire and began unconsciously coiling it into perfect loops, a nervous habit he had developed during his apprenticeship.

Tony studied his best employee with the shrewd eyes of a man who had been running a small business in Newark for over twenty years. He had seen good workers come and go, watched some burn out from the physical demands of the job, others move on to bigger companies or start their own operations. But Marcus was different – reliable, skilled, and honest to a fault. Losing him would be a disaster Tony couldn't afford.

"Look, Marcus, I get it. Sometimes a man needs a hobby. But sword fighting? Come on. Why not take up bowling like a normal person? Join a softball league. Hell, learn to play poker. But waving around sharp pieces of metal? That's how you end up in the emergency room, or worse."

Marcus set down the coiled wire and met Tony's gaze directly. "It's not just waving around sharp pieces of metal. It's a sport. An art form. These people train for years, decades even. There's strategy involved, technique, discipline."

"Discipline?" Tony snorted. "You want discipline? Try running a small business in this economy. Try dealing with customers who think electricity should be free and contractors who pay their bills six months late. That's discipline."

The conversation was interrupted by the arrival of Mrs. Chen, an elderly woman who lived in one of the renovated brownstones on the north side of the city. She clutched a plastic grocery bag filled with what appeared to be electrical outlets and light switches, her face bearing the expression of someone who had been dealing with home improvement projects far beyond her expertise.

"Excuse me," she said hesitantly, her voice carrying a slight accent. "My grandson, he try to fix bathroom light. Now nothing work upstairs. You can help?"

Tony's demeanor immediately shifted into professional mode. "Of course, Mrs. Chen. Marcus here will take a look at what you've got and we'll send someone over this afternoon." He shot Marcus a meaningful look. "Won't we, Marcus?"

"Absolutely," Marcus replied, already reaching for his tool bag. This was the part of the job he actually enjoyed – solving problems, figuring out what had gone wrong and making it right again. It was satisfying work, even if it wasn't particularly glamorous.

As Mrs. Chen explained the situation in a mixture of English and what sounded like Mandarin, gesturing expressively with her free hand, Marcus found his mind wandering. He imagined himself in white fencing gear, mask obscuring his face, holding a slim blade that caught the light as he moved through the precise choreography of an attack sequence he had watched online the night before.

"Marcus!" Tony's sharp voice snapped him back to reality. "Mrs. Chen asked you a question."

"Sorry," Marcus mumbled, feeling heat rise in his cheeks. "What was that?"

Mrs. Chen repeated her question about whether the problem might be related to the circuit breaker, and Marcus launched into a detailed explanation of how electrical circuits worked and what might have caused the outage. As he spoke, he noticed Tony nodding approvingly – this was the Marcus he knew, the one who could diagnose electrical problems with the confidence of a doctor reading symptoms.

After Mrs. Chen left with assurances that help would arrive by three o'clock, Tony returned to their earlier conversation with the persistence of a dog with a favorite bone.

"See, that's what I'm talking about. You're good at this stuff, Marcus. You've got natural instincts for electrical work. Why throw that away to play with swords?"

Marcus felt a familiar frustration building in his chest. "I'm not throwing anything away. I'm talking about taking lessons a couple nights a week. It's not like I'm quitting my job to become a professional... what do you call them... a musketeer or something."

"Musketeer," Tony repeated flatly. "Right. And I suppose next you'll be wanting time off to go fight duels in the park."

"It's not duels, Tony. It's sport fencing. They use electronic scoring systems and everything. It's completely safe."

Tony walked over to the small window that looked out onto the street, watching the afternoon traffic crawl past in the humid August heat. Newark in summer was like working inside an oven, and the air conditioning unit in the shop had been making concerning noises for weeks – another repair that would have to wait until they had time and money to address it properly.

"You know what's not completely safe?" Tony said without turning around. "Climbing around on scaffolding forty feet off the ground. Working with live electrical panels. Crawling through basements that haven't been properly ventilated in fifty years. But we do it anyway, because it's our job. Because it puts food on the table and pays the rent."

Marcus understood the implication. Tony wasn't just worried about the safety aspects of sword fighting – he was worried about his employee's priorities, about whether Marcus was starting to lose focus on the work that mattered.

"I hear what you're saying," Marcus said carefully. "But this isn't about the job. This is about having something in my life besides work. Something that challenges me in a different way."

Tony finally turned away from the window, his expression softer but still skeptical. "Look, kid, I've been doing this a long time. I've seen guys go through midlife crises before. Usually it involves buying a motorcycle or dating someone half their age. Sword fighting is a new one for me, but the principle is the same. You're looking for something to make you feel young again, or tough, or I don't know what."

"Maybe you're right," Marcus admitted. "But maybe that's not necessarily a bad thing."

The admission seemed to catch Tony off guard. He had been prepared for argument, for defensive protests, not for this kind of honest self-reflection.

"Besides," Marcus continued, "I already signed up for the introductory class. It starts next Thursday."

Tony's eyebrows shot up toward his receding hairline. "You already signed up? Without talking to me about the schedule?"

"It's Thursday night, seven to nine. We're usually done with calls by six, and I wasn't scheduled for any overtime work this week."

"That's not the point, Marcus. The point is that you made a commitment without thinking about how it might affect your work here. What if we get an emergency call? What if Mrs. Chen's electrical problem turns out to be more complicated than we thought and we need to work late?"

Marcus felt his patience beginning to fray around the edges. "Then I'll handle it, same as always. But I can't put my entire life on hold just in case something might happen with work."

The conversation was heading toward an argument, and both men seemed to realize it at the same time. Tony rubbed his forehead with the palm of his hand, leaving his gray hair sticking up at odd angles.

"All right," he said finally. "All right. You want to take fencing lessons, take fencing lessons. Just don't come crying to me when you poke somebody's eye out."

Marcus smiled for the first time since the conversation had started. "I don't think that's how it works, Tony. They wear masks and everything."

"Yeah, well, we'll see."

The rest of the afternoon passed in relative normalcy. Marcus drove out to Mrs. Chen's house and discovered that her grandson had indeed created an impressive electrical disaster by attempting to install a dimmer switch without first turning off the circuit breaker. It took two hours to sort out the wiring and replace a blown fuse, but Mrs. Chen was so grateful she insisted on sending him home with a container of homemade dumplings.

That evening, Marcus sat in his small apartment eating Mrs. Chen's dumplings and watching fencing videos on his laptop. His living room was spartanly furnished – a secondhand couch, a coffee table made from a piece of reclaimed wood and some metal pipes, and a bookshelf containing mostly technical manuals and a few paperback novels he had picked up at yard sales.

The apartment reflected Marcus's practical nature and limited budget, but it also revealed something else: a life that had become routine to the point of stagnation. He went to work, came home, ate dinner, watched television, and went to bed. Weekends were spent doing laundry, grocery shopping, and catching up on sleep. It was a perfectly functional existence, but it lacked the spark of genuine excitement or purpose.

As he watched Olympic fencers move across his laptop screen with fluid precision, Marcus tried to imagine himself learning those same movements. Could his hands, so used to gripping wire strippers and voltage meters, adapt to holding a sword? Could his body, accustomed to the practical movements of manual labor, learn the elegant geometry of attack and defense?

The doubts that had been lurking at the edges of his consciousness began to surface. Tony wasn't entirely wrong – this was an unusual hobby for someone in his situation. Most of the people in the fencing videos looked like they came from a different world entirely, a world of private lessons and expensive equipment and country club memberships.

But something stubborn in Marcus's nature pushed back against these doubts. He had always been good at learning new skills, at figuring out how things worked and mastering the techniques required to do them well. Electrical work itself had once seemed impossibly complex, full of mysterious concepts and dangerous variables. Yet he had learned it, had become good at it, had even found satisfaction in it.

Why should fencing be any different?

The following Thursday evening found Marcus standing outside the Hoboken Community Center, a converted warehouse building that housed everything from yoga classes to pottery workshops. The parking lot was filled with an eclectic mix of vehicles – hybrid sedans, aging SUVs, and a few expensive European cars that seemed out of place in the industrial neighborhood. Marcus had changed out of his work clothes into a clean pair of jeans and a polo shirt, but he still felt underdressed and uncertain as he approached the glass doors that led to the main entrance.

Inside, the building buzzed with the activity of various evening classes. Through one doorway, he could see a group of middle-aged women stretching on yoga mats while soft music played in the background. Another room contained what appeared to be a book club, their animated discussion punctuated by gestures toward paperback novels and wine glasses. The smell of clay and paint from the art studios mixed with the industrial scent of the old warehouse, creating an atmosphere that was both creative and slightly overwhelming.

Marcus followed the signs toward the gymnasium, his work boots echoing against the polished concrete floors. The closer he got to his destination, the more his nervousness transformed into something resembling excitement. This was really happening – he was about to try something completely outside his normal experience, something that had nothing to do with electrical codes or circuit breakers or the familiar rhythms of his daily routine.

The gymnasium was larger than he had expected, with high ceilings and fluorescent lighting that reminded him uncomfortably of Tony's shop. But instead of electrical equipment and wire spools, this space was set up with what looked like long rectangular strips marked out on the floor. At one end of the room, a woman in her forties was arranging equipment on a folding table – masks that looked like metallic mesh, strange-looking swords with curved hand guards, and what appeared to be electronic scoring devices with trailing wires.

She looked up as Marcus entered, offering a welcoming smile that immediately put him more at ease. Her dark hair was pulled back in a practical ponytail, and she wore a fitted athletic shirt that suggested someone who stayed in excellent physical condition without making a show of it. There was something in her bearing that reminded Marcus of the military veterans he sometimes worked with on construction sites – a quiet confidence that came from extensive training and discipline.

"You must be Marcus," she said, extending her hand for a firm handshake. "I'm Elena Vasquez. I run the fencing program here. Welcome to what I like to call the most civilized form of combat known to humanity."

Marcus found himself smiling at her description. "Thanks for letting me try this out. I have to admit, I'm not entirely sure what I've gotten myself into."

Elena laughed, a sound that was both warm and slightly mischievous. "That's probably the most honest thing anyone has said to me in weeks. Most people show up convinced they're going to be the next Olympic champion after watching too many movies. The fact that you're admitting you don't know what to expect tells me you might actually have the right attitude for this."

Over the next few minutes, other students began filtering into the gymnasium. Marcus was surprised by the diversity of the group – there was a teenager who looked like he might still be in high school, a woman in her sixties who moved with the careful precision of someone managing arthritis, a man about Marcus's age wearing a business suit who had apparently come straight from an office job, and several others who defied easy categorization. It wasn't the homogeneous group of privileged athletes he had been half-expecting.

Elena gathered the newcomers together at one end of the gym while the more experienced students began their own warm-up routine. Marcus watched them out of the corner of his eye, noting how they moved through stretching exercises that seemed designed specifically for fencing. Their movements had a fluidity that spoke of years of practice, but there was nothing intimidating about their demeanor. If anything, they seemed genuinely enthusiastic about the presence of new students.

"Before we put any equipment in your hands," Elena began, "I want to talk about what fencing actually is and what it isn't. It's not sword fighting in the medieval sense – we're not trying to hack each other to pieces with broadswords. It's not about anger or aggression or proving how tough you are. Modern sport fencing is about strategy, timing, and precision. It's about reading your opponent, finding the perfect moment to attack, and executing techniques that have been refined over centuries."

She picked up one of the swords from the equipment table, holding it with the casual familiarity of someone who had been handling such weapons for decades. The blade was thin and flexible, nothing like the heavy medieval swords Marcus had seen in movies. In Elena's hand, it looked almost delicate, more like a precision instrument than a weapon.

"This is a foil," she explained, demonstrating a few basic movements. "It's one of three weapons used in modern fencing, and it's what we'll be starting with tonight. The target area is limited to the torso, and only the tip of the blade can score touches. The rules might seem arbitrary at first, but they're designed to teach fundamental techniques that apply to all forms of swordplay."

Elena demonstrated the basic stance, and Marcus tried to mirror her movements. His legs felt awkward in the required position, with one foot pointed forward and the other angled to the side, his weight distributed in a way that felt unnatural after years of standing and walking in work boots. His arm position was even more challenging – holding the imaginary sword with his wrist straight and his elbow controlled, maintaining a position that was both relaxed and ready for instant action.
